Question #1 to both candidate Romney and Obama in the 2nd debate should be: "American business is sitting on unprecedented levels of cash; they have enjoyed historically high levels of profit over the last ten years while paying historically low levels of taxes. What specific measures do you plan to use to get American business to share some of their prosperity with their employees who have been getting a shrinking share of the economic pie over that time"?

The last president to concern himself with the quality of American jobs was Jimmy Carter. He proposed reforming labor law to restore balance to a system that tilts in favor of employers as a result of Republican determination in passing Taft-Hartley over the veto of Harry Truman. Carter also favored an Equal Rights Amendment to insure that women could not be discriminated against in terms of compensation.

America's workforce has seen a downward spiral in wages, compensation, and job security that has continued unabated since Ronald Reagan was president.

As we are alternately amused and outraged by the GOP's panic-stricken writhing over the jobs stats, it's also maddening that the whole focus is on how the numbers are affecting the horserace. We haven’t heard a single word about the desperate need for a living wage law. The war on unionized labor continues unabated.

Many of the gains have been in the low-paying health care, service and warehousing sectors. Many of the jobs are part-time. Fabulously wealthy tax-avoiders are hiring more cleaners, chefs, personal assistants, packing clerks and the like. The average CEO still earns 380 times the salary of the average worker.

No matter who wins this election, all signs point to a bipartisan agreement raising the retirement age and cutting cost of living increases for Social Security recipients. The lucky duckies who mow the lawns, empty the bedpans and ship the iPads will now work until they drop. This is the new normal. We may be crawling out of our hole, but we’re emerging from it with our quality of life terribly diminished, our very lives foreshortened.

The extreme wealth inequality and the criminal behavior of the financial class that caused the crisis in the first place have not been rectified. The Galts and the Gekkos are still running wild and free. The top 1% still own 40% of all the wealth. It’s only a matter of time before another economic mudslide buries us anew inside that deep, deep hole.

I find this article alarmingly misleading as what was printed was not a complete gun, but rather the least-critical of the two halves of the receiver required to make a working gun. The upper receiver, buffer assembly, springs, fire control group, lower parts kit, bolt, bolt carrier, barrel, muzzle device, gas block and gas tube were all metal parts made by via traditional, highly-specialized forging and machining processes.

There's no such thing as a plastic gun and there never has been aside from hilarious urban legends started by Die Hard 2 of all things, even the most advanced plastics and ceramics cannot withstand the pressures created by firing a bullet. Even if they could and you made the slide, barrel, and frame entirely from non-metallic substances it would be impossible to fully exclude metal from a gun. Bullets need the high specific gravity of metal to be effective at covering any distance or creating anything more than shallow minor wounds, cartridge casings need to be brass or steel since walls of the casing need to be thin and elastic, and springs powerful enough to cycle the gun/feed ammo from a magazine/drop the firing pin can only be made from spring steel.

@Steve Glazer: No, that is incorrect. The so-called "Copyright clause" or "Patent clause" or "intellectual property clause" you reference contains no explicit requirement for patents or copyrights.

It simply grants Congress the authority to, as you quoted, "promote the progress.. by securing for limited times... the exclusive right...". There no requirement that this must be done with a patent or copyright. It could very well be done by some other sui generis system (as with plant variety protection).

I suppose if you are an originalist, you could argue that the Founders wanted patents because that's what they had at the time, but if that's the logic, we should go back to a 14 year copyright term.

The fact that Article 1 Section 8 is the basis for the modern patent and copyright system is irrelevant, and the original poster remains incorrect in his assertion that "our founding fathers thought it proper to include patent by its name in the Constitution."

The constitutional argument about patents is rubbish. This is an area of frequent misunderstanding. The U.S. Constitution doesn't create rights out of thin air; it *preserves* them by granting limited powers to each branch of the federal government. Those powers are explicitly moderated the Bill of Rights -- for example, by declaring that Congress shall make no law abridging freedom of speech.

The intellectual property clause that patent and copyright maximalists love to cite (Article I, section 8, clause 8) is one of many enumerated powers granted to the legislative branch in Article I, alongside the power to declare war, to mint currency, and so forth. As Michael Masnick wrote in a recent Techdirt article (below), "All that clause does is give permission to Congress to create such laws -- but solely for the purpose of "promot[ing] the progress of science and the useful arts."

Permission is not a mandate. Congress is not compelled to use every iota of power granted by the people. (Otherwise, as Mike points out, where is my Letter of Marque?) It has the authority to amend or repeal IP laws without a constitutional amendment. Whether it has the political courage to do so is another story.

See http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20120920/03014020445/can-we-kill-myth-t...

A few comments on some of the above:

1. The Constitutional provision quoted above indeed explicitly defines the essence of a "patent" and a "copyright.," as understood in 1787 or 2012. Whether those specific words are used, or some other word, has no substantive significance. In any event, the one example given above of an alternative "sui generis" form of intellectual property -- "plant variety protection" -- is also called a "patent." (See 35 USC 161, "Patents for plants.") But it just as well may be called something else, and still be a "patent."

2. It is true, however, that the Constitution does not define the specific terms and conditions for obtaining a patent or a copyright. That was left to Congress. And one of the very first acts that Congress passed pursuant to the Constitution was the 1790 Patent Act (which says something about the importance that the Founding Fathers and Congress placed on patents). Since then, the terms and conditions have changed from time to time.

3. To talk about radically and unilaterally changing, if not eliminating, the U.S. patent system in some of the extreme ways suggested here -- although PERHAPS Constitutional -- is impractical and unrealizable in today's global economy and society. There are now numerous international treaties and agreements that bind the signatories to all sorts of intellectual-property protections and conditions. Indeed, we have special courts to enforce such laws (e.g., the U.S. International Trade Commission).

Patent is a form of lawful monopoly whose genesis is as old as our Constitution. It is one of the handful of enumerated constitutional rights. There is a very good reason why our founding fathers thought it proper to include patent by its name in the Constitution.

Copyright is not mentioned in the Constitution, and not surprisingly, copyright and trademark are beasts of entirely different nature.

Unless we intend to abolish patent by enacting a Constitutional Amendment AND having it ratified by the requisite number of states within our Union, we better work with it.

Of late, the Federal Circuit and the Supreme Court have been waging a silent war with each other. The Supreme Court has made its displeasure felt over the Federal Circuit's doctrinal directions. And the Federal Circuit continues its passive-aggressive disobeyance by playing a cat-and-mouse game with the Supreme Court. So both courts essentially provide lifetime job security to patent litigation lawyers and trolls. Well, it is certainly their job to interpret statutes that our Congress does manage to pass once in a while. And not even our Constitution requires a court to turn in its best work. What I cannot live with is the fact that no justice on the bench in either court (or their vaunted law clerks) came to the appointment with actual experience in patent law. I doubt that they ever took an introductory course in patent law when they were in law school. Go figure.

I teach at a community college in Oregon. Several years ago when the housing market cratered and the economy tanked, everyone who lost a job headed for the college to enroll in classes. Our enrollments soared, and all classes had long wait lists. Many of the students who "enrolled" did so only to obtain financial aid benefits, and did so by dutifully showing up for class the first week, and then quickly disappeared after cashing their financial aid checks. However, the majority of unemployed (or underemployed) students returning to college or coming for the first time were honestly there trying to get an education and turn their employment profile into something marketable.

Enrollments are now flat, and this fall for the first time in years some classes had to be cancelled for lack of sufficient enrollment. In my small department, we looked all summer to hire two different people to teach part time, and didn't have any qualified candidates apply.

On my way to work each day I see other signs of a recovering economy. There are new houses being built and new businesses opening all over town. Not in large numbers, but at a very healthy pace.

I don't need to read statistics to know that the economy is slowly recovering. I can see with my own eyes. President Obama deserves an enormous amount of credit for staying the course and pressing FORWARD through a very difficult and contentious time in our country's history.

As ever, I am up late and exhausted in October…

So it goes. I love winning!
